children.text: Okay, I need to translate this Java code into Fortran.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Let me first understand what the Java code is doing.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The program reads three words, removes all non-alphabetic characters and converts them to lowercase. Then it generates all permutations of these three words concatenated together.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Then, for each student's input, it checks if their processed input matches any of these permutations.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: If it does, output ACC, else WA.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: The Java code creates all 6 possible permutations of the three words. So perm1 to perm6.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: In Fortran, we can create an array or list containing these permutations. But the order is all possible permutations of the three words. Since there are 3! = 6 possible orders, each concatenation of the three words in those orders.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Wait, the code in Java uses:

perm1: word1 + word2 + word3

perm2: word1 + word3 + word2

perm3: word2 + word1 + word3

perm4: word2 + word3 + word1

perm5: word3 + word2 + word1

perm6: word3 + word1 + word2 So these are all 6 permutations. So in Fortran, I can generate these six combinations and store them in an array or list.

children.text: - Generate the six permutations as concatenated strings.

Create an array of six elements, each being a permutation. Then read N students, for each:

After that, generate the permutations. For example:

perm(1) = w1 // w2 // w3

perm(2) = w1 // w3 // w2

perm(3) = w2 // w1 // w3

perm(4) = w2 // w3 // w1

perm(5) = w3 // w2 // w1

perm(6) = w3 // w1 // w2

But need to check if these permutations are correctly generated.

Then, for each student, read their input line, process it into test_case, then check if it equals any of the permutations. But since all the perm(i) and test_case are processed to have no non-letter characters and are lowercase, the comparison is straightforward. So, putting it all together.

But according to the problem's input format, the three words are on separate lines, then the integer is on the next line, then the student's inputs follow. So assuming that the integer is on a line by itself, the code after reading the integer should read the rest of that line (which is empty), then read the next lines as student inputs. But if the integer is followed by other data on the same line, the Java code would skip that data. So the Fortran code should mimic that. So in the Fortran code, after reading the integer with read(*, *), the next read(*, '(a)') will read the rest of the current line (including any characters after the integer).

In Fortran, this can be done as follows:

read(*, '(a)') line

read(line, *) students

This way, the entire line is read into 'line', and then parsed for the integer.

read(*, '(a)') line

read(line, *) students

Then, loop students times, reading each student's input line.

children.text:
This way, the code correctly reads the integer from its own line, and then reads the next students lines. So, integrating this into the code:

program main
    use processing
    implicit none
    character(len=:), allocatable :: w1, w2, w3, test_case
    character(len=:), allocatable :: perm(6)
    character(len=1000) :: line
    integer :: students, i, j, io
    logical :: matched

    ! Read and process the three words
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w1 = process_str(line)
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w2 = process_str(line)
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w3 = process_str(line)

    ! Generate permutations
    perm = [character(len=len(w1)+len(w2)+len(w3)) :: &
        w1 // w2 // w3, &
        w1 // w3 // w2, &
        w2 // w1 // w3, &
        w2 // w3 // w1, &
        w3 // w2 // w1, &
        w3 // w1 // w2  ]

    !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Read number of students
    read(*, '(a)') line
    read(line, *) students

    ! Process each student's input do i = 1, students
        read(*, '(a)', iostat=io) line
        if (io /= 0) exit
        test_case = process_str(line)
        matched = .false. do j = 1, 6
            if (test_case == perm(j)) then
                matched = .true. exit
            end if
        end do
        if (matched) then
            print '(a)', 'ACC'
        else
            print '(a)', 'WA'
        end if
    end do
end program main

children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Sample code:

module processing
contains
    function process_str(s) result(res) implicit none
        character(len=*), intent(in) :: s
        character(len=:), allocatable :: res
        integer :: i, j, ascii
        character :: c

        allocate(character(len=len(s)) :: res)  ! Max possible length
        res = ''
        j = 0
        do i = 1, len(s)
            c = s(i:i)
            ascii = ichar(c)
            if ((ascii >= 65 .and. ascii <= 90) .or. (ascii >= 97 .and. ascii <= 122)) then
                j = j + 1
                if (ascii >= 65 .and. ascii <= 90) then
                    res(j:j) = char(ascii + 32)
                else
                    res(j:j) = c
                end if
            end if
        end do
        res = res(1:j)  ! Truncate to actual length
    end function process_str
end module processing

program main
    use processing
    implicit none
    character(len=:), allocatable :: w1, w2, w3, test_case
    character(len=:), allocatable :: perm(6)
    character(len=1000) :: line
    integer :: students, i, j
    logical :: matched

    ! Read and process the three words
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w1 = process_str(trim(line))
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w2 = process_str(trim(line)) read(*, '(a)') line
    w3 = process_str(trim(line))

    ! Generate permutations
    perm = [ &
        w1 // w2 // w3, &
        w1 // w3 // w2, &
        w2 // w1 // w3, &
        w2 // w3 // w1, &
        w3 // w2 // w1, &
        w3 // w1 // w2  &
    ]

    !

Let's write a function that takes a string and returns the processed version. But in Fortran, functions can return character strings. So:

function process_str(s) result(res)
    character(len=*), intent(in) :: s
    character(len=256) :: temp !
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
assuming maximum length after processing is 256
    integer :: i, j
    character :: c
    j = 0
    temp = ''
    do i = 1, len_trim(s)
        c = s(i:i) if ((c >= 'A' .and. c <= 'Z') .or. (c >= 'a' .and. c <= 'z')) then
            j = j + 1
            if (c >= 'A' .and. c <= 'Z') then
                temp(j:j) = char(ichar(c) + 32)
            else
                temp(j:j) = c
            end if
        end if
    end do
    res = temp(1:j)
end function

But Fortran requires the function's result to have a fixed length. So perhaps using an allocatable character variable. So, modifying the function to:

function process_str(s) result(res)
    character(len=*), intent(in) :: s
    character(len=:), allocatable :: res
    character(len=len(s)) :: temp
    integer :: i, j
    character :: c

    j = 0
    temp = ''
    do i = 1, len(s) c = s(i:i) if ((c >= 'A' .and. c <= 'Z') .or. (c >= 'a' .and. c <= 'z')) then
            j = j + 1
            if (c >= 'A' .and. c <= 'Z') then
                temp(j:j) = char(ichar(c) + 32)
            else
                temp(j:j) = c
            end if
        end if
    end do
    res = trim(temp(1:j))

Okay, I need to translate this Java code into Fortran. Let me first understand what the Java code is doing. 

The program reads three words, removes all non-alphabetic characters and converts them to lowercase. Then it generates all permutations of these three words concatenated together. Then, for each student's input, it checks if their processed input matches any of these permutations. If it does, output ACC, else WA.

First, I'll need to handle string manipulation in Fortran. Let's break it down step by step.

1. **Reading Inputs:** In Java, they read three lines, process each by removing non-letters and lowercasing. In Fortran, I'll need to read three lines as well. But Fortran's string handling is a bit different. Also, processing the strings to remove non-alphabetic characters. Hmm. How to do that?

In Java, replaceAll("[^a-zA-Z]", "") removes all characters except letters. So, in Fortran, I need to loop through each character of the string and keep only the alphabetic ones. Then convert to lowercase.

Wait, but Fortran is case-insensitive for variable names, but the processing here is case-sensitive. Wait, the original code converts everything to lowercase. So after removing non-letters, we make them all lowercase.

So for each input word, process by:

- Iterate each character, check if it is a letter (a-z, A-Z). If so, keep it, else skip.
- Then convert the remaining characters to lowercase.

So in Fortran, for each input string, create a new string that includes only the letters, then convert to lowercase.

2. **Generating permutations:** The Java code creates all 6 possible permutations of the three words. So perm1 to perm6. In Fortran, we can create an array or list containing these permutations. But the order is all possible permutations of the three words. Since there are 3! = 6 possible orders, each concatenation of the three words in those orders.

Wait, the code in Java uses:

perm1: word1 + word2 + word3

perm2: word1 + word3 + word2

perm3: word2 + word1 + word3

perm4: word2 + word3 + word1

perm5: word3 + word2 + word1

perm6: word3 + word1 + word2

So these are all 6 permutations. So in Fortran, I can generate these six combinations and store them in an array or list.

3. **Processing student inputs:** For each student's input, process it similarly (remove non-letters, lowercase), then check if it matches any of the six permutations.

So the steps are:

- Read three words, process each into w1, w2, w3.

- Generate the six permutations as concatenated strings.

- Read number of students, then for each student's input, process it and check against the permutations.

Now, how to implement each part in Fortran.

Similarly for the others.

Then, for each student input, process the same way, then check if it's equal to any of the permutations.

In Fortran, when reading a line, leading and trailing spaces are part of the string. So when processing, we need to loop through each character in the input line, check if it's a letter, and append.

function process_str(s) result(res)
    character(len=*), intent(in) :: s
    character(len=256) :: temp ! assuming maximum length after processing is 256
    integer :: i, j
    character :: c
    j = 0
    temp = ''
    do i = 1, len_trim(s)
        c = s(i:i)
        if ((c >= 'A' .and. c <= 'Z') .or. (c >= 'a' .and. c <= 'z')) then
            j = j + 1
            if (c >= 'A' .and. c <= 'Z') then
                temp(j:j) = char(ichar(c) + 32)
            else
                temp(j:j) = c
            end if
        end if
    end do
    res = temp(1:j)
end function

Potential issues:

Sample code:

module processing
contains
    function process_str(s) result(res)
        implicit none
        character(len=*), intent(in) :: s
        character(len=:), allocatable :: res
        integer :: i, j, ascii
        character :: c

        allocate(character(len=len(s)) :: res)  ! Max possible length
        res = ''
        j = 0
        do i = 1, len(s)
            c = s(i:i)
            ascii = ichar(c)
            if ((ascii >= 65 .and. ascii <= 90) .or. (ascii >= 97 .and. ascii <= 122)) then
                j = j + 1
                if (ascii >= 65 .and. ascii <= 90) then
                    res(j:j) = char(ascii + 32)
                else
                    res(j:j) = c
                end if
            end if
        end do
        res = res(1:j)  ! Truncate to actual length
    end function process_str
end module processing

program main
    use processing
    implicit none
    character(len=:), allocatable :: w1, w2, w3, test_case
    character(len=:), allocatable :: perm(6)
    character(len=1000) :: line
    integer :: students, i, j
    logical :: matched

    ! Read and process the three words
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w1 = process_str(trim(line))
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w2 = process_str(trim(line))
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w3 = process_str(trim(line))

    ! Generate permutations
    perm = [ &
        w1 // w2 // w3, &
        w1 // w3 // w2, &
        w2 // w1 // w3, &
        w2 // w3 // w1, &
        w3 // w2 // w1, &
        w3 // w1 // w2  &
    ]

    ! Read number of students
    read(*, *) students

    ! Process each student's input
    do i = 1, students
        read(*, '(a)') line
        test_case = process_str(trim(line))
        matched = .false.
        do j = 1, 6
            if (test_case == perm(j)) then
                matched = .true.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (matched) then
            print *, 'ACC'
        else
            print *, 'WA'
        end if
    end do
end program main

But in Java's code, after reading the integer with in.nextInt(), it reads the next line (including any remaining characters on the same line) with in.nextLine().

Then, after reading the integer 3, the rest of the line is ' student1_input', which would be processed as the first student's input. Then, the next reads would be student2_input and student3_input.

But in Java's code, after reading the integer with in.nextInt(), the code reads in.nextLine() which consumes the rest of the current line. Then, the next in.nextLine() calls read the following lines.

So to replicate that behavior in Fortran, after reading the integer, we need to read the rest of the line (possibly empty) to move the input to the next line.

But in Fortran, the first read(*, '(a)') after the integer will get the rest of the line, which may include part of the student's input if there's data after the integer.

So assuming that the integer is on a line by itself, the code after reading the integer should read the rest of that line (which is empty), then read the next lines as student inputs.

But if the integer is followed by other data on the same line, the Java code would skip that data. So the Fortran code should mimic that.

So in the Fortran code, after reading the integer with read(*, *), the next read(*, '(a)') will read the rest of the current line (including any characters after the integer). That would be the first student's input, but that's not desired.

Thus, the correct approach is to read the entire line containing the integer, parse the integer from it, then proceed.

So, how to read a line, parse the integer from it, and then proceed.

In Fortran, this can be done as follows:

This way, the entire line is read into 'line', and then parsed for the integer. This leaves the input pointer at the next line.

So, integrating this into the code:

program main
    use processing
    implicit none
    character(len=:), allocatable :: w1, w2, w3, test_case
    character(len=:), allocatable :: perm(6)
    character(len=1000) :: line
    integer :: students, i, j, io
    logical :: matched

    ! Read and process the three words
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w1 = process_str(line)
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w2 = process_str(line)
    read(*, '(a)') line
    w3 = process_str(line)

    ! Generate permutations
    perm = [character(len=len(w1)+len(w2)+len(w3)) :: &
        w1 // w2 // w3, &
        w1 // w3 // w2, &
        w2 // w1 // w3, &
        w2 // w3 // w1, &
        w3 // w2 // w1, &
        w3 // w1 // w2  ]

    ! Read number of students
    read(*, '(a)') line
    read(line, *) students

    ! Process each student's input
    do i = 1, students
        read(*, '(a)', iostat=io) line
        if (io /= 0) exit
        test_case = process_str(line)
        matched = .false.
        do j = 1, 6
            if (test_case == perm(j)) then
                matched = .true.
                exit
            end if
        end do
        if (matched) then
            print '(a)', 'ACC'
        else
            print '(a)', 'WA'
        end if
    end do
end program main

Wait, but when generating the permutations, the code uses [character(len=...) :: ...], which sets the length of each permutation to the sum of the lengths of the three words. But since the three words are processed and concatenated, their lengths are fixed. However, in Fortran, array constructors require that all elements have the same length. So if the sum of the lengths varies between permutations, this could be a problem. Wait, no. For example, if the permutations are different orders of the same three words, their concatenation lengths are the same. Because each permutation is the three words concatenated in some order. But when declaring the perm array, how to set the length. Using len(w1) + len(w2) + len(w3) is possible. So:

perm = [character(len= len(w1) + len(w2) + len(w3)) :: ... ]

But in Fortran, the length must be a constant expression. Wait, no. In Fortran 2003, the length can be a variable expression if using an allocatable array. But in this case, the perm array is declared as character(len=:), allocatable :: perm(6). Then, when assigning the array, each element's length is set. However, in Fortran, all elements of a character array must have the same length. So the code must ensure that all permutations have the same length. Which they do, since each permutation is the concatenation of the three words. For example, the length of each permutation is len(w1) + len(w2) + len(w3).

So when generating the permutations, each is exactly that length. So when creating the array, the length is set to that sum. So the code perm = [ ... ] with each element having the same length is correct.

But the code may need to compute the length as total_len = len(w1) + len(w2) + len(w3), then set the perm array to character(len=total_len).

But how to do this in Fortran.

In the code above, the array constructor uses:

perm = [character(len=len(w1)+len(w2)+len(w3)) :: ... ]

But len(w1) is the length of the allocatable string. This should be valid.

However, in Fortran, when using an array constructor with a type-spec, all elements must be of that type. So each element must have the specified length. But when we concatenate the three words, the resulting string's length is exactly len(w1)+len(w2)+len(w3), so each permutation element will have that length. So this should work.

Thus, the code should correctly generate the permutations.

Testing this code:

For example, if w1 is "a", w2 is "b", w3 is "c", then each permutation is "abc", "acb", "bac", "bca", "cba", "cab", each of length 3.

Another example: if the three words are "hello", "world", "test", then each permutation is 5+5+4=14 characters. Each permutation is the concatenation of the three words in different orders.

So the code should generate the permutations correctly.

Now, the final check in the loop:

For each student's test_case, compare to each perm(j).

If any match, output ACC.

Otherwise, WA.

In Fortran, the comparison is case-sensitive and exact, which matches the Java code.
